question_text: According to the thermodynamic analysis in the paper, what specific waste heat recovery mechanisms enable combined cycles to achieve significantly higher energy and exergy efficiencies compared to single cycles in LNG regasification systems, and how do the reported efficiency values demonstrate this performance advantage?
standard_answer: The paper demonstrates that combined cycles achieve superior performance through systematic waste heat recovery mechanisms that extract additional work from thermal energy that would otherwise be wasted. According to the analysis, 'Combined cycles generally utilize the waste heat that comes out of the exhaust in order to improve the cycle efficiency. As a result, efficiency of the combined cycles increases to 50%, which is much higher than the conventional cycles.' This fundamental approach allows combined cycles to cascade energy utilization across multiple temperature levels, thereby reducing overall exergy destruction. The performance advantage is quantitatively demonstrated by the paper's comprehensive evaluation showing that 'among the considered cycles, the highest energy and exergy efficiencies are about 86.3% and 80.0% respectively; which is related to the combined cycles.' This represents a substantial improvement over single cycles, where the lowest energy and exergy efficiencies occur in other applications of LNG cold energy cycles with values of only 7.39% and 7.95% respectively. The waste heat recovery mechanism works by capturing thermal energy from high-temperature exhaust streams and converting it to additional mechanical work through secondary power cycles, while simultaneously utilizing the LNG cold energy as an effective low-temperature heat sink to enhance condensation processes and improve overall thermodynamic performance.
